section: CONSULTANT'S “ENDORSEMENT” means the right to use the CONSULTANT'S name, fame, nickname, autograph, voice, facsimile, signature, photograph, likeness, and image solely in ADAMS GOLF'S internal documentation.
explanation: This definition severely limits the scope of the endorsement.  Typically, an endorsement agreement grants the company the right to use the endorser's image and likeness in external advertising, marketing, and promotional materials aimed at the public.  Restricting it to "internal documentation" makes the endorsement almost worthless from ADAMS GOLF's perspective.  This raises a significant question about the purpose of the agreement and contradicts the "WHEREAS" clause which states ADAMS GOLF desires to obtain the right to use the name, likeness and ENDORSEMENT of CONSULTANT in connection with the advertisement and promotion of ADAMS GOLF'S PRODUCT.

section: Notwithstanding paragraphs 4A, 4B and 4C above, CONSULTANT shall be entitled to endorse and play the [*****]. The parties expressly agree that CONSULTANT may permit [*****] the use of CONSULTANT'S name and/or likeness in [*****] print and/or television advertisement provided that this is executed in a manner consistent with [*****] past [*****] advertising practice using similarly situated professional golfers with competing golf club endorsement agreements that include [*****]. If [*****] use of CONSULTANT varies from past practice of utilizing similarly situated professionals, CONSULTANT will take action to remedy the situation [*****]. If CONSULTANT participates directly in any [*****] sponsored photo shoots for advertising or PR, CONSULTANT shall wear his ADAMS GOLF [*****]. The parties further expressly agree that CONSULTANT'S endorsement of the [*****] shall not include the right to place a [*****] logo on his ADAMS GOLF [*****] or the ADAMS GOLF [*****]. If CONSULTANT'S relationship with [*****] terminates during this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall be permitted to replace the [*****] endorsement with another [*****] endorsement under the same terms and conditions expressed herein.
explanation: This section allows Watson to endorse [*****] which seemingly contradicts the exclusivity clause in section 4A, 4B, and 4C, especially considering this endorsement includes the use of Watson's name and likeness in advertising. However, the conditions attached to the [*****] endorsement introduce significant ambiguity. The reference to "past advertising practice using similarly situated professional golfers" is vague and open to interpretation, creating an ambiguity within the agreement. It's unclear what specific past practices are being referenced and how they would be objectively determined.

section: Notwithstanding paragraphs 4A, 4B and 4C above, CONSULTANT shall not be required to wear ADAMS GOLF [*****] in [*****] ads.
explanation: This section provides another exception to the exclusivity clause outlined in sections 4A, 4B, and 4C, where it states Watson doesn't have to wear any Adams Golf merchandise in [*****] ads. This introduces a contradiction because the document also states that Watson has to wear Adams Golf [*****] in all ads. This creates ambiguity as to which terms should be enforced, leading to disputes over contractual obligations.

section: During the term of this Agreement, CONSULTANT will conduct himself at all times with due regard to public morals and conventions, unless CONSULTANT acts in a manner that brings additional media attention to the ADAMS GOLF'S PRODUCT.
explanation: This clause creates a contradiction.  It starts by requiring CONSULTANT to conduct himself with due regard to public morals. However, it creates an exception that completely undermines the initial requirement.  The phrase "unless CONSULTANT acts in a manner that brings additional media attention to the ADAMS GOLF'S PRODUCT" implies that behavior contrary to public morals is acceptable, and even desirable, if it generates positive media coverage for ADAMS GOLF. This completely undermines the meaning of the first part of the sentence.

section: During the term of this Agreement, CONSULTANT will conduct himself at all times with due regard to public morals and conventions, unless CONSULTANT acts in a manner that brings additional media attention to the ADAMS GOLF'S PRODUCT. If the value of CONSULTANT'S ENDORSEMENT is materially reduced or impaired because CONSULTANT: A.committed or shall commit any public act that involves moral turpitude, B.commits or violates any material foreign, U.S., federal, or other applicable state or local law, C.commits any act which brings him into public disrepute, contempt, scandal or ridicule, or which insults or offends the community, D.makes any statements in derogation, in any material respect, of ADAMS GOLF or any of its affiliates or any of their respective PRODUCT or services and such statement is made to the general public or becomes a matter of public knowledge, then at any time after the occurrence of such act, thing or statement, ADAMS GOLF shall have the right, in addition to its other legal and equitable remedies, to immediately terminate this Agreement, by giving written notice to CONSULTANT. ADAMS GOLF must exercise its right of termination within ninety (90) days of its senior management becoming aware of the conduct giving rise to the right of termination.
explanation: Section 12 contains an internal contradiction regarding the grounds for termination.  The initial statement allows for behavior contrary to public morals if it brings media attention to the product. However, the subsequent subsections (A-D) list specific actions (moral turpitude, violating laws, public disrepute, disparaging ADAMS GOLF) that *would* give ADAMS GOLF the right to terminate the agreement. This creates a conflict. Does ADAMS GOLF want Watson to generate media attention (even through questionable behavior) or do they want him to strictly adhere to a high moral standard? The ambiguity creates uncertainty about what actions would actually trigger termination.

section: Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, in the event that CONSULTANT dies or is unable to play tour golf at all, ADAMS GOLF may terminate this Agreement on thirty (30) days' written notice. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT and/or CONSULTANT'S estate shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: Requiring repayment from the CONSULTANT's estate "for that period of the Agreement not performed" in the event of death is potentially problematic. The Agreement makes no explicit allowance for events where CONSULTANT is simply no longer living and thus can't fulfill endorsement duties. While a contract can address unforeseen circumstances, the clause as written could be interpreted as an unfair penalty against the estate, particularly if the death was sudden and unexpected. This contradicts general principles of contract law which try to prevent unjust enrichment.
